facts.text: Smt. Vimla (plaintiff) filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the court of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara, for decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites in Sch. A, movable properties in Sch. B, possession, management and account of properties in Sch. C, and institutions in Sch. D alleged to be private family religious endowments.
Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade (plaintiff's father) died on August 31, 1955.
Plaintiff claimed entitlement to suit properties upon father's death, but defendant wrongfully possessed them.

Plaintiff valued Sch. C and D under s. 28 of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid court-fee of Rs. 275/-. Lands in Sch. A valued at 30 times assessment, buildings separately.
On June 28, 1956, Subordinate Judge held Rs. 34,577/- court-fee paid by plaintiff adequate on office objection.
Defendant filed written statement on September 9, 1956, objecting inter alia to valuation and court-fee.
Trial court raised issue on adequacy of court-fee.
On February 13, 1957, defendant applied for Commissioner to value properties; court dismissed and declared fee adequate.
Defendant filed Revision Petition 272 of 1957 to High Court of Judicature at Bangalore; HC set aside order, directed trial court to ascertain value, appoint Commissioner if needed, decide afresh.
Subordinate Judge appointed Commissioner; report submitted, defendant objected, further and supplemental reports submitted.

Subordinate Judge held Sch. D extra commercium, fixed fee for possession; Sch. D trust properties, s.28 applies as rival trustees dispute; houses on revenue lands at market value or 30x assessment; valued Sch. A lands at Rs. 7,74,665/-, house-sites Rs. 27,625/-. Plaintiff paid additional fee.

Plaintiff and defendant filed separate revision petitions to High Court of Mysore; HC heard Advocate-General, confirmed Sub Judge except for Nelliyadi Beedu, directed trial court to determine if extra commercium after evidence.
Defendant preferred appeal to Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136 against High Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defendant has a right to invoke revisional jurisdiction of the High Court under s.115 CPC against orders determining adequacy of court-fee paid by plaintiff on the plaint.
Whether court-fee adequacy is a matter only between plaintiff and State, or defendant can contest and seek revision.

petitioner_arguments.text: By s.12(2) of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 (Act 14 of 1955), defendant invested with right to contest adequacy of court-fee in trial court and move High Court in revision if contrary order passed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 s.12(2)

court_reasoning.text: Court-fees Act enacted to collect revenue for State, not to arm contesting party with weapon to obstruct trial. Question of proper court-fee primarily between plaintiff and State; defendant has no grievance or right to appeal/revision thereon unless jurisdiction involved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant may contest in trial court to assist, but no statutory right to move High Court in revision.

court_reasoning.text: Revisional jurisdiction under s.115 CPC strictly conditioned; no refusal/assumption of jurisdiction or illegality here. s.12(2) only enables raising plea in trial court, not revision to HC. s.19 allows inquiry/commission but doesn't arm defendant for revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications by defendant on court-fee when no jurisdiction question involved; frustrated suit progress for five years.

holdings.text: Defendant has no right to move High Court in revision against trial court's order on adequacy of court-fee paid by plaintiff; such matters between plaintiff and State.
High Court erred in exercising revisional jurisdiction on court-fee issue at defendant's instance absent jurisdiction defect.

precedents_cited.relevance: many precedents may be found for course of proceedings on court-fee objections

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held that High Court erred in entertaining defendant's revision petitions on court-fee adequacy; defendant lacks locus standi to seek revision thereon as it is matter between plaintiff and State; process obstructed suit trial for nearly five years.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside implicitly by holding error in entertaining revisions.

key_quotes.text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing purpose of court-fee legislation

key_quotes.text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant, when no question of jurisdiction was involved.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding against High Court's exercise of jurisdiction
